I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) launched the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC) Program in 1997 to help participating countries overcome barriers to 
trade and other impediments to development, and thereby create new economic opportunities 
and reduce poverty. There are now eight countries in the program: Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, 
People’s Republic of China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. 
ADB is the program secretariat.1  
 
2.  At the Fifth Ministerial Conference on CAREC (5th MC) in October 2006, the CAREC 
ministers  endorsed  a  comprehensive  action  plan  for  the  program2 based  on  four  pillars: 
knowledge  and  capacity  building;  regional  infrastructure  networks;  trade,  investment,  and 
business development; and regional public goods.3 The action plan will broaden and deepen the 
program by including new policy and sectoral areas of activity, while focusing on the priority 
sectors of transport, energy, trade facilitation, and trade policy, and by giving greater attention to 
the policy dimension of regional cooperation.4 To underscore the priority accorded to knowledge 
and capacity building, the 5th MC also endorsed the establishment of a CAREC Institute to 
coordinate CAREC initiatives in research, dialogue, and capacity development. 
 
3.  The knowledge and capacity-building pillar of the action plan will combine the research 
and analysis strengths of participating countries and multilateral organizations to improve the 
capacity to design and implement mutually beneficial regional initiatives. A network of research 
institutes and specialized experts will be created in the region, in partnership with international 
experts. These experts will engage key government officials, representatives of the business 
community and civil society, and other stakeholders. Finally, mid-level and senior officials in 
CAREC countries will be trained for effective regional cooperation.5 In its CAREC regional 
cooperation strategy and program, ADB recognized the need to increase technical assistance 
for capacity development in participating countries.6 ADB’s regional cooperation and integration 
strategy also highlights the role of capacity development in intensifying cooperation.7 As a 
participant in both the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) program and the CAREC program, the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) has urged the use of a modified form of the GMS Phnom 
Penh Plan (PPP)8 in the CAREC program. At the 5th MC, the PRC suggested that ADB use 
$500,000 from the PRC Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund for this purpose. 
This regional technical assistance (RETA) will put this generous support into operation. The 
RETA design and monitoring framework is shown in Appendix 1.9

II.  ISSUES 
4.  Capacity development must be viewed in the wider context of transition in Central Asia 
and  neighboring  countries,  particularly  following  the  breakup  of  the  Soviet  Union  and  the 
formation of new nation-states. The loss of the central apparatus of the Soviet Union led to 
severe  economic  difficulties  immediately  after  the  Soviet  years.  But  it  also  opened  up 
opportunities to revive the historic trade routes of Central Asia, to supply world markets with the 
rich energy resources of the region, and to link the region with the rest of the world through 
dynamic trade and communication. The CAREC countries must cooperate toward a common 
future to make the most of these opportunities. 
 
5.  CAREC countries differ in geographic, social, economic, and political characteristics, 
and in natural resource endowments. Kazakhstan has the largest land surface and the lowest 
population density, and generates about half of regional gross domestic product. In contrast, 
Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan have small land areas, limited natural resources, and low per 
capita incomes. Features and challenges common to these countries include poor access to 
markets, environmental challenges, vulnerability to natural disasters, low-quality social services, 
and difficult governance conditions.   
 
6.  While other regional cooperation efforts have had a positive impact on the development 
of institutions, Central Asian and neighboring countries still lack human resources, especially 
those needed to promote policies and management practices for more open, stable, market-led 
economies. The shortage of skilled personnel has become critical as a result of migration 
immediately after the Soviet period. With their civil services poorly resourced and insufficiently 
trained, the countries are ill equipped to combat poverty, and to build more stable societies that 
can  promote,  and  benefit  from,  economic  growth  and  sustainable  development.  Human 
resource development must therefore be a core concern of any regional cooperation effort.    
 
7.  Regional integration efforts in Central Asia and neighboring countries will have a better 
chance  of  success  insofar  as  capacity  development  can  promote  dialogue  among  major 
stakeholders toward greater stability and prosperity in the region. These stakeholders include 
the  private  sector,  academe,  emerging  media  and  civil  society  organizations,  the  donor 
community, and government agencies. Continuing dialogue toward a shared regional vision is a 
vital part of the proposed capacity development program. 
 
8.  Strong state capacity for regional cooperation in Central Asia and neighboring countries 
can be supported by developing a core group of reform agents among mid-level and senior 
government officials in each country who have the analytical and negotiating skills to formulate 
and implement mutually beneficial regional initiatives. The challenge is to create a critical mass 
of civil servants with a regional perspective who can translate their knowledge and skills into 
concrete programs and activities for regional cooperation. The proposed capacity development 
program  will  provide  selected  mid-level  and  senior  government  officials  with  learning 
experiences that will strengthen the capacity of these officials and their institutions to plan, direct, 
manage, implement, and evaluate programs, plans, and activities for national development and 
regional cooperation.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The capacity development program for  CAREC will  make regional cooperation and 
integration more effective and give it greater momentum. The program will (i) train senior and 
mid-level government officials involved in regional cooperation in the skills needed to identify, 
plan, and effectively implement mutually beneficial initiatives; and (ii) deepen understanding of 
the importance of regional cooperation and the costs of noncooperation. Earlier TA completion 
reports cited consensus building and mutual understanding among participating countries as 
vital in overcoming inertia in regional cooperation.10    
 
10.  In  the  short  term,  the  capacity  development  program  will  create  a  core  group  of 
government  officials  who  can  (i)  advise  their  respective  cabinets  on  regional  cooperation 
matters, and (ii) effectively and efficiently carry out agreements with neighboring countries. The 
program is expected to help build a network of officials skilled in regional cooperation and able 
to help lead dialogue with their governments, the business community, and civil society.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Under the RETA, all components of the program will be designed and implemented in 
close  consultation  with  CAREC’s  national  focal  point  (NFP)  in  each  country,  and  with 
universities, training centers, and research institutes in the region. 
 
12.  The  RETA  will  (i)  implement  selected  courses  in  strategic  management  and 
organizational  change,  public  policy  analysis  and  public  administration,  global  economic 
competition, public-private partnerships in development, and key success factors in regional 
cooperation, among others; (ii) introduce on-site courses in the CAREC region and identify 
partner training institutions that can implement selected courses; (iii) through a small grants 
component, support (a) research on regional cooperation and integration issues by developing 
member-country experts, and (b) existing research institutes and networks within the region; 
and (iv) in consultation with a range of key stakeholders, develop a detailed proposal for 
establishing the CAREC Institute to lead the research, dialogue, and capacity development 
initiatives of the CAREC program. The implementation of the RETA, especially the design and 
execution of the training and research programs, will be based on a training needs analysis and 
learning indicators to be prepared by the program manager at the start of the RETA. Moreover, 
the RETA will build on the lessons and extensive experience of other subregional cooperation 
programs, such as the GMS Program and PPP for capacity development. In the design and 
conduct  of  training  programs  and  workshops,  synergies  with  the  PPP  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank Institute will be explored.11 
 
13.  A  structured  series  of  short  and  medium-length  courses12 will  be  developed  and 
implemented in the first 18 months to jump-start the capacity development program and lay the

foundations for longer-term activities in support of regional cooperation. Courses will deepen 
knowledge and skills in development management and public policy. They will also allow the 
participants to work together on common issues from a regional perspective. Such learning 
experiences are expected to help promote a regional approach to problem solving and facilitate 
consensus building. Course materials will be posted on the ADB Web site. 
 
14.  Specific learning programs are envisioned for the CAREC NFPs,13 who anchor the 
regional effort and must sustain its momentum.  
15.  In conjunction with the start-up courses, the relevant knowledge and skills needs of 
senior and mid-level government officials will be assessed. Appropriate institutions with the 
requisite  expertise  and  translation  facilities  to  conduct  developed  courses  in  appropriate 
languages will also be identified and, together with the proposed faculty, will be included in a 
network of capacity-building providers. 
16.  A  competitive  research  grants  component  will  be  developed  and  implemented  to 
promote research by experts from CAREC countries on regional cooperation. (See Appendix 2 
for an outline of the anticipated administrative procedures.) In addition, a few small grants not 
exceeding a total of $40,000 in any given year, may also be negotiated directly with selected 
research institutes to build local capacity for policy analysis.  
  
17.   This RETA will not cover the establishment of the CAREC Institute, but it will provide 
support for the development of a detailed program and budget proposal for the establishment of 
the institute as a center of excellence for the region, for consideration by CAREC. The proposal 
will learn from and build on all relevant activities and studies done under the RETA, as well as 
consultations with a broad range of stakeholders. In addition, the proposal will present options 
for the structure, management, and medium-term work program of the institute in its three core 
areas of (i) research and analysis in regional cooperation and development of research and 
analysis networks in the region, (ii) dialogue to build understanding and interest in regional 
cooperation, and (iii) capacity development to create a pool of qualified and competent mid-level 
and senior officials to promote and manage regional cooperation initiatives in Central Asia. (See 
Appendix 2 for a diagram of the proposed input flow.) Until more resources can be mobilized, 
the  institute  is  expected  to  be  run  on  a  small  scale,  with  the  use  of  information  and 
communication technologies (Internet, Web sites, video conferencing) to cut costs.14 
   
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $990,000. ADB will finance $490,000 of this 
amount from its TA funding program and will administer the balance of $500,000, to be provided 
by the Government of the PRC. Detailed cost estimates are given in Appendix 3.   
 
                                                 
13 Each CAREC country has an NFP, whose key role is to ensure effective coordination (i) among concerned 
government agencies and other interested parties in matters related to regional economic cooperation, and 
(ii) between the government and the CAREC secretariat. In particular, NFPs are involved in and help coordinate 
activities of the Senior Officials’ Meeting, all sector coordinating committees, and project-specific working groups in 
which the country is involved. Given the pivotal role of the NFP, this function is usually given to a senior 
representative of the government agency in charge of overall planning, such as the ministry of finance or of the 
economy, or the state planning agency. To ensure continuity and consistency in the work of the NFP, countries are 
encouraged to ensure some permanence to these appointments.  
14 The Institute may begin small-scale operations with seed financing from ADB, but it is hoped governments within 
and outside the CAREC region, as well as other multilateral and bilateral development partners, would consider 
providing support in the future.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.   ADB’s Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) will be the Executing Agency of the 
RETA and will be responsible for overall RETA administration. A program manager will report to 
CWRD. The RETA is expected to begin in January 2007 and be completed by June 2008. 
 
20.   A steering committee chaired by the director of the Country Coordination and Regional 
Cooperation Division, CWRD, will oversee the RETA. The committee members will be the 
national focal points (NFPs) and the program manager. The committee will screen programs 
and identify partner institutions, and will meet periodically to review progress and resolve issues. 
A full-time program secretariat initially based at ADB headquarters will provide logistical and 
administrative support.  
 
21.   The RETA will require consulting services, as follows: a program manager (international, 
8 person-months), a full-time program officer (national, 18 person-months), and an institutional 
development specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). (See Appendix 4 for the terms of 
reference for these consultants.) In addition, several short-term consultants (international and 
national) will be required for course development and implementation in all countries and for 
short-term research. all the consultants will be engaged by ADB according to its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time). Office equipment will be 
procured for this RETA according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (April 2006, as amended 
from time to time). After the RETA, all equipment will be retained by the CAREC unit and used 
in other capacity development program activities. 
 
22.  Appropriate  information  on  RETA  activities,  including  relevant  course  and  training 
program materials and outputs from the small research grant program, will be disseminated 
widely through ADB’s CAREC Web site and the quarterly CAREC newsletter. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the People’s Republic of China, and (ii) ADB 
providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $490,000 on a grant basis for Central 
Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation:  Capacity  Development  for  Regional  Cooperation  in 
CAREC Participating Countries, Phase I, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

ANTICIPATED ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES FOR COMPETITIVE GRANTS PROGRAM 
AND REGIONAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES 
 
 
1.  The regional technical assistance (RETA) will include a competitive research grants 
component to promote research by experts from Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
(CAREC) countries on relevant aspects of regional cooperation and to support existing research 
institutes and networks in the region. 
 
2.  A public call for research proposals from relevant researchers and research institutes will 
be made through appropriate media. Proposals from institutions and individuals will be accepted. 
Proposals will be assessed, and grants decided, by a blind committee of three staff members of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) (one each from the Office of Regional Economic Integration, 
the Office of Cofinancing Operations, and the Country Coordination and Regional Cooperation 
Division, CWRD).  
 
3.  No  grant  shall  exceed  $20,000  or  extend  beyond  the  completion  of  the  RETA 
(June 2008).  Grant  disbursements  will  be  made  as  follows:  one  third  of  the  total  upon 
acceptance of the grant agreement by the research institution; one third midway through the 
agreed grant period, after the grantee submits a midterm report acceptable to ADB; and one 
third at the end of agreed grant period after the grantee submits a final report acceptable to ADB. 
 
4.  Further procedural and administrative details will be agreed on with relevant ADB offices 
before the call for research proposals is issued.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  A program manager, a program officer, and an institutional development specialist are 
expected to be engaged for the regional technical assistance (RETA) as outlined in the following 
paragraphs. In addition, short-term international and national consultants may be engaged to 
assist in assessing (i) knowledge and skills needs, and (ii) local research and training institutes 
in Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) countries. All consultants will be 
engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) according to its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (April 2006, as amended from time to time) and other arrangements satisfactory to 
ADB for the recruitment of domestic consultants. 
 
 
A.  Program Manager 
 
2.   The  program  manager  will  help  lead  the  program  and  manage  its  day-to-day 
implementation, with the support of a program officer (national consultant; see below). The 
program manager will be based at the ADB headquarters in Manila and will report to the Head 
of ADB’s CAREC Unit (team leader). Candidates with background in capacity development 
program management, training assessment, and training delivery will be given preference. A 
contract for 8 person-months is being considered, to start with, but could be extended, subject 
to continued good performance, the availability of technical assistance resources, and project 
needs. 
 
3.   The program manager will have the following specific tasks: 
 
(i)  Managing the CAREC capacity development program, including the identification 
of courses and their design. 
 
(ii)  Analyzing the training needs of participating countries and developing learning 
indicators for the capacity development program.  
 
(iii)  Developing  a  simple  and  practical  system  for  measuring  the  results  of  the 
capacity development program. 
 
(iv)  Helping teach and supervise the logistics for selected training programs. 
 
(v)  Coordinating  with  course  faculty,  universities,  think  tanks,  and  research  and 
academic institutions to identify best locations for training. 
 
(vi)  Evaluating course programs and training providers. 
 
(vii)  Coordinating with CAREC governments to determine how to obtain well-qualified 
candidates for training programs. 
 
(viii)  Interacting  with  institutions  and  agencies  to  design  research-based  capacity 
development programs. 
 
(ix)  Preparing and updating training calendars.

Appendix 4    13 
(x)  Managing the CAREC capacity development program budget and assisting in 
securing additional funding. 
 
(xi)  Preparing progress reports and making presentations to the steering committee. 
 
(xii)  Undertaking other tasks determined jointly with Asian Development Bank staff 
members managing the program. 
 
 
B.  Program Officer  
 
4.  This officer, in close collaboration with the program manager and the team leader, will 
support and manage the day-to-day implementation of the program. He or she will be based at 
ADB headquarters and will report to the program manager and the team leader. Candidates 
must have a postgraduate degree in economics, social science, or public administration and 
public policy; proven experience in managing technical assistance projects; and at least 5 years 
of professional experience in dealing with a range of stakeholders. Previous experience in 
capacity-building  programs  in  both  academic  and  non-academic  settings  will  be  a  distinct 
advantage. A contract for 12 person-months is being considered, to start with, but could be 
extended,  subject  to  continued  good  performance,  the  availability  of  technical  assistance 
resources, and project needs. 
 
5.  The specific tasks of the program officer will include, but will not be limited to, the 
following:   
 
(i)  Assuming  responsibility  for  program  management  requirements  at  ADB 
headquarters  to  ensure  smooth  relations  between  field  operations  and  the 
headquarters. 
 
(ii)  Assisting in the coordination, integration, and monitoring of the various activities 
under the RETA. 
 
(iii)  Assisting in supervising, coordinating, and reviewing the work of domestic and 
international  consultants particularly with reference to the following: 
 
  (a)  preparing  course  designs  and  learning  materials  for  the  various 
  training programs; and 
 
  (b)  monitoring the progress of participants in the learning programs. 
 
(iv)  Participating in consultations and monitoring missions to CAREC countries as 
required. 
 
(v)  Assisting in the preparation and updating of the consultants’ work plans. 
 
(vi)  Preparing background papers on development management and public policy 
issues  in  Central  Asia  relevant  to  the  design  and  conduct  of  the  training 
programs, particularly issues and challenges in regional integration.

14  Appendix 4 
(vii)  Consolidating data and providing support to the program manager and other 
academic and non-academic staff in dealing with relevant governmental and 
other expert institutions and individuals.  
 
(viii)  Assisting in organizing and implementing steering committee meetings.  
C.  Institutional Development Specialist 
 
6.   The  institutional  development  specialist  will  advise  on  and  help  develop  the  draft 
program and budget proposal for the CAREC Institute, and will report to the team leader. A 
contract for 1.5 person-months is being considered for a start. 
 
7.  The specific tasks of the institutional development specialist will include the following: 
 
(i)  Supporting the CAREC secretariat in finalizing the draft program and budget 
proposal for consideration by CAREC senior officials. 
 
(ii)  Facilitating consultation with key stakeholders on the structure, management, 
and work program of the CAREC Institute. 
 
(iii)  Assisting in synthesizing stakeholder inputs into clear options for the structure, 
management, and work program of the CAREC Institute.  
 
(iv)  Assisting in defining the research, dialogue, and training focus and program of 
the CAREC Institute.
